While watching i couldn't wait to see him again and when he does, i was scared about what is going to happen, what puss is going to do?Goldilocks and bears are pretty charming and they aren't that antagonistic as Jack Horner (Death himself isn't hunting but for puss so im not comparing him). They are well developed and it is hard to not like them despite they are against main characters.

reviews.review_title: More than meets the eye about appreciating life and those in it
reviews.content: This movie somehow changed my view of death. And now thanks to Joel Crawford wonderful storytelling and animation style and I came too see this movie as more of lesson in life than just as an entertainment. It shows that even the most badass and fearless of hero like Puss. Have fear and insecurities despite his fame and bravado. And how it comes to appreciating the love ones you left out in your life. For that i am happy and grateful what this movie showed me. And especially how the creator are slowly changing this character's story and personality for the better. I am sure we can expect great things for this character stories in the future.

I love the new Graphics and Colors there better than the old one this is the best movie for this year I love this movie so much it brings my childhood back and I really love puss in boots sooo much. And the new characters are really amazing too and I love the story a lot and it really made me enjoy the time watching them he movie on Dec 23, 2022 my family enjoyed it too. I hope DreamWorks makes another puss in boots later on in the years and I really love the Puss in Boots Cast & Crew the after so great and just one compliment Kitty Soft Paws Looked really Cute and Puss in boots together W Movie.

I really enjoyed the Puss in Boots sequel. Less focus on detail seemed to make it attractive yet cheap animation without compromising on quality. Probably, this new style will become more popular in new animations, imitating Spider-Man. The combination of adult elements and jokes between the colorful childlike world of the animation is well done. Fight scene are busy and breathtaking, and the fight scenes are very action-packed and similar to anime's. Perhaps the message of the story is more understandable by adults than children. I personally enjoyed the character of death. His presence with music and dark moments made gave me goose bumps everytime. He was one of the best animation villains who had a small presence. However, the story may have taken a repetitive path and adventure, but I think it has done it's mission correctly and is worth watching for one and a half hours. Perhaps only a few questions remain unanswered but I shouldn't expect too high of an animation that os aimed for kids.And I won't expect much from my first review and bad Grammer.

I went into the movie theater with zero expectations and got a wonderful experience and my hopes up for the future of DreamWorks animation and further Shrek sequels!The story flows naturally, even if the numbee of side characters make it seem like there's too many storylines to follow. But that doesn't happen! Everything is neatly done and all the story arcs have great endings by the end of the movie. They managed to give every character a change to shine, without giving up any of the fun gags and shenanigans.The choice of dropping the framerate during action scenes is a master's trick in my opinion, the flow of the characters makes these shots very unique and differentiate them from the rest of the movie.The themes were well thought out and come together at the end of the movie, the payoff is worth the incredible journey.Will definitely rewatch this before it leaves theaters.

reviews.review_title: The film is good but dubbing was awful
reviews.content: The movie is interesting, the children enjoyed it very much. But the Bulgarian dubbing was terrible! Goldilocks and the bears talked disgustingly. The children did not understand what they were saying. We have to explain them what they are saying. The stunt doubles had chosen to speak a dialect from a region that was incomprehensible. I don't even know how they would translate this in English.It was awful experience for us. We have to relax and enjoy, but we were afraid how to explain what you have in mind.I think that in Bulgaria you have a big problem with the dubbed. Most of people won't understand the story.

Honestly one of the best movies or kids movies I've ever seen, definitely top tier DreamWorks movie next to how to train your dragon, incredibly more colorful and vibrant and especially to a cat and Hispanic person it feels a lot more personal and makes everything more lovable and enjoyable, even still you don't need to be a cat or Hispanic to enjoy this movie, it still has its laughs and the art style is as great yet different as spider man's art style that made it so nice, from the great art, enjoyable characters, an interesting narrative with enjoyable characters and especially villains, all with a lovable cat main character, the movie is perfect in nearly all regards and already finished my second play though, it's a movie all ages and backgrounds will love. If you haven't already please go watch it you won't be disappointed, hell I'm only a teen who plays games all day and hates just going out, but I'm so glad I did that night, and with all the mid tier/terrible movies coming out, gives all the more reason to give this one a try.

The Last Wish was pretty entertaining. The story was really good and funny. It is very colorful and is filled with a lot of imagination. Looks like they used similar animation techniques from Spider-verse in the action sequences, and it brought a lot of great dynamics and style into them. The voice acting was also pretty strong too. I don't really have many problems with the movie, nothing that is really worth mentioning anyway. All in all , The Last Wish is a good movie with good music and even a couple of great moments for the adults watching as well. Meaning everyone will be entertained, no matter the age.

Definitely NOT recommend for kids under 12. Crazy, messy and not really kind, greatly disappointed.. The first part is a masterpiece to compare with "this", the graphics is strange, no simpathy to ugly and grotesque personages.. Journey to the magic forest just reminds an acid trip, colors irritate eyes and constant action -nerves . The plot itself is very poor, looks like chip Hollywood blockbusters of 90's. Really don't understand so high rating, any Disney movie of the last years is great deal better! The dog is probably the one who "save" the situation a bit, it's nice and one of the most mentally healthy "person" in this asylum🙈

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" was filled with the same lovable characters reprising their roles from the previous films. Antonio Banderes and Salma Hayek Pinault's character's enduring relationship does not disappoint. The additional new characters are just as funny, charming, and comical. The storyline was easy to follow for all ages. A definite must-watch, at least a couple of times to catch the one-liners in both English and Spanish. The incredible background character antics and animation really keep the movie moving in a positive way. Overall, a comical, adventurous and heartwarming story of lovable characters.

I was not the biggest fan of the original. But this movie was one of my favorites I've seen all year, and one of my favorite animated movies of all time! Everything about this movie is beyond excellent: the writing, the animation, the emotion, the humor, the voices, THE FIGHT SCENES, everything! The Big Bad Wolf is without a doubt the best movie villain of 2022 and one of the best animated movie villains of all time! I laughed, I cried, and I jumped for joy! It's a movie that makes you want to experience it again and again! I've already seen it twice in theaters, and I cannot wait to see it again!

reviews.review_title: Just as i just expected,another classic movie of DreamWork
reviews.content: Dark with Light,Day and Night combined,Funny and Scary,Happy and Sad. This "kid movie" bring me nostalgia at first then bring me all the emotion i could feel,it deserves to be nominated for it graphic especially when its in 20fps when fight begin. Thank you DreamWork (again). My little brother of 7 year old "Just LOVE the smell of"this movie. Thsi movie show how family matter,how all loved one is more important than new one and most importantly how life is priceless,it teach us that no matter if you are a legend,or rich,poor,old,young,a politician or a doctor we simply die equally and that why i rate that movie a 9 out of 10. Bravo DreamWork.

reviews.review_title: The effects of into the spider-verse
reviews.content: I would have never expected Puss in boots of all things would end up being one of my favorite animated movies of all time!! The animation is gorgeous and, while obviously inspired by into the spider-verse, keeps its own style which fits the fairytale narrative. Death is a fantastic villain and the scenes with him have a complete tonal change. Hes such a fantastic villain. The other villains are also great. I love all of the characters and they all have some great arcs, especially Puss. Everything in this movie is amazing. Its an exhilarating thrillride that you never want to stop. There is also "swearing" in this movie. In a kids movie!! Just amazed at the quality of the movie. BTW there are no actual F-bombs or anything like that.

reviews.review_title: The best film of the year
reviews.content: Before reading this review I want you to know that this film is quite dark for dreamworks film. This is not a film for small children. This was just my cup of tea. This may sound insane but the sequel to a bad spin off of Shrek is a masterpiece in so many ways. The biggest surprise I've had in years. Firstly, this movie balances three villains perfectly, (technically six but anyway.) I won't talk about them much but the best character is the wolf by an extremely long shot. All, and yes I do mean all, of the characters are so entertaining.I can easily say this should win best picture or at least be nominated for best animated picture. Another thing to mention is that the trailer in my opinion should not be watched to get an idea of the film except the animation. Oh the animation. It is probably the best looking thing in the Dreamworks catalogue. They also use it in some of the greatest ways especially with the wolf villain.Not to mention the fight sequences. Those both use animation to its fullest potential and are incredibly well choreographed. Please watch it. Dreamworks both needs it and deserves it for this amazing amazing film .

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of 2022
reviews.content: I saw this movie in the theater and was amazed by the animation. It was crazy good. I have always been in love with dream work studios and puss in boots. Character design is amazing, totally recommend seeing this with your kids!! What ever karens are saying about Deaths character design is too scary, don't listen to them. I saw this with my 6 year old sister and she wasn't scared. His design isn't even that scary. To all of the Karens out there, if you don't want your kids to see an amazing movie, you probs make your 10 year old watch Cocomelon. Again, totally recommend this movie if your bored! It's one of DreamWorks best movie!

reviews.review_title: A genius return of the cat with boots
reviews.content: This movie perfectly captures the world of Shrek and the atmosphere of the first movie, only with a better story.As in the first movie the stakes weren't that emotional, this movie improves on the storytelling. The characters are well written and funny. This movie does not sacrifice it's story for some comedic jokes, but rather incorporates very funny jokes with a witty story with some emotional real stakes for the main characters.The bad guys are well designed and either extremely funny or actually terrifying (or both).In conclusion I think this movie really captures the magic of the world of Shrek with a style that perfectly captures puss in boots.

This movie is something else is much better than expected. The characters are good and the story is simple. Everything about this movie is just right. I got the chills every time death came, he is just so well written. Everything felt dark and sort of muffled. There are all lot of emotional parts in there too like how goldilocks realized that she didn't need the wish. But that she had everything she wanted all along. Also jack horner who is just such a funny evil character that just murders all of his people and doesn't care even a bit. All in all its just a really really good movie and I would recommend it to everyone! So go and watch it!

Finally i watched this movie. Tbh this is one of the best animated movie i ever watched. I think it is kind of scary for small kids. But this movie is so amazing. The villain is so good. I love the wolf ( the villain ). He is so cold and that whistle gives us some chills. I need another sequel of this movie. This movie has became one of my favorites and i will definitely recommend this movie to everyone. I think small children would be scared of this. The villain might be so scary for small children. And also the dog is kind of an interesting and weird character. I definitely need new adventures of the team friendship.

I watched the original Puss in Boots as a kid. I thought it was alright, but because I watched it as a kid, it stuck with me.When I saw the news about a new Puss in Boots getting a sequel, I was so excited. Years pass by as I was waiting to get more news about it, but it's finally here!Like most people who have reviewed this movie, my expectations were blown away!The Music was superb! The Art and Animation screamed personality and passion! And let's not forget about the story and it's characters! Everything about it screams fun! But then I was surprised by the dark twist this story went for.It didn't even bother me, if anything, I was intrigued.In this movie, the legendary Puss in Boots is stripped away from his confidence as he literally faces death. All he has is a single life. He's lost the other eight, being completely careless of his past lives.We have Kitty Softpaws, a character who was in the previous movie (Don't even need to watch the first movie to see the relationship between Puss and Kitty) and Perrito, a new character who is just as important as the other two.Just wanted to say that the very last part of the movie had my heart pounding as I'm watching Puss fight Death (He's literally a character). Seeing Puss fight for his life made me smile, because it really felt like Puss has changed for the better. I felt so genuinely happy that I almost shed a tear.I don't want to go over everything because one, too lazy, and two, you really should go see the movie for yourself and experience all of what this movie has to offer! (That's if you haven't seen it yet) Because it's criminal that this movie still isn't getting the attention it truly deserves.I went to go see this movie six times in the theater.Just thought I'd show my support to Dreamworks...01/21/23.

I really enjoyed the movie because of how they changed the artstyle, animation and the style of the narrative, the jokes weren't destroying the sentimental value of the film and were actually funny. The voice acting also had a huge spotlight for me, especially during songs that i found amazing. The movie shows a more mature take on a shrek character so hopefully they do the same for Shrek himself. The movie has some flaws without a daubt, but the good parts heavily overshadowed them. Death is an actually scary villain for once in animated films from past years and i love it so much. Death as a villain is perfect, materializing a fear many of us have allows the character of Puss in boots to become more relatable, especially with the anxiety attack scene, it captures what it feels like and how our little friends can help us through out it.Love it.

It is cringy, creepy, unfunny and with weak creativity about its characters. I am going to stop going to dreamworks movies anymore cus they are way over hyped from bots. I dont recommend you bring children less than 10 to the movie and adults as well cus it is a lost of time. The quality of animation was decent which is expected when you pour tons of money but that is all it has. I am sorry for losing my time and money. I walked out on the 20th min when I didnt smiled at least once from the experience till then. Shrek and Puss in Boots 1 was 1 million times better form the 1st sec I still rewatch it from time to time, but this piece of ... I would NOT even finish it the first time. Disney are corrupt wacks it is obvious for every with logical and critical thinking after it sees even the first quarter of the movie. Sorry not sorry.

reviews.review_title: Best animated movie of the decade
reviews.content:
Surprising how deep "kids" movies can get. It is a
movie that entertains kids but at the same times gives a very very very meaningful message. Everybody internally runs from something but at the end trying over compensate this void with external things is just an illusion. Sometimes are fears make us act in ways we hurt people that love us. Life is about establishing meaningfull connections. Love, friendship, family complete us, not power or money. We can spend all are lifes running from are deepest fears, but it is a decision we make. As I said, deep movie.Also has a good pace, you never feel like its slow or fast, hits the sweet spot.

Puss in Boots the Last Wish was probably one of the most surprising movies to come out last year a sequel to the first Puss in Boots movie which was a spin-off the Shrek series has somehow in many peoples eyes undoubtedly reached the upper echelons of Dreamwork's catalogue. The movie tackles extremely mature themes from Puss learning to except his own mortality and the inevitability of death to living life to the fullest even through traumatic events. The Story is very simple and yet incredibly effective the way the Wishing Star ties in the three main groups of characters and what each want from it is done incredibly and how at the end each character gets their wish (except one) without the wishing star and whilst that might seem like a very generic plot the characters, animation, themes all make seem so fresh and new, and that brings me to my next point the animation is incredibly stunning and beautiful it feels like a fresh take in animation and it reminds me of when animation company's pushed the boundaries and made such creative and expressive art which feels so rare these days, the perfect mix of the 2D and 3D animation is seamless and the drops in frames in certain scenes, the small details in scenes, and how colorful and distinct every scene is it just makes the viewing experience and spectacle incredible. Now for me the strongest part of this movie were it's characters which is surprising to me because in a movie with nearly 10 main characters it perfectly juggles them with enough development and screen time that makes you care about each and everyone of them even Perrito who many thought would be an annoying gag character is used so well throughout the movie and his scene where he helps Puss through his panic attack like a real life therapy dog is so emotional and well done, now this brings me to the strongest part of the movie it's villains now of course everyone already knows about Death so I won't talk to much about him, but he is now objectively one of the greatest Dreamwork's villains ever created alongside Lord Shen, Lord Farquaad, and even the Fairy Godmother the way the tone of a scene changes when he enters is so dramatic and perfectly executed his motives make complete sense and the final confrontation where he excepts that Puss has changed and he won't try two kill him anymore is so well done and fits perfectly with his character, and also there is Big Jack Horner who is in my opinion one of the funniest characters in the movie his dynamic with Jiminy Cricket is hilarious and also how he is pretty much evil incarnate for no reason is just funny and I really liked that they did that because for the past decade we have had sympathetic villains who we are meant to feel bad for and Disney twist villains who feel like a cheap way of trying to subvert the audience so just having a character be evil for the sake of being evil is just hilarious to me and also his death where instead of some moment of sorrow or regret for his actions he simply accepts that he was a horrible human being. Overall this movie was near perfection my only gripe is that I feel Puss's initial retirement from his heroic life early in the film could have been more fleshed out but other than that this movie checked every box for a timeless classic and it also proved that Dreamwork's can still make incredible, mature, funny, and creative movies.

Muy buen, very good movie the quality is amazing I'm surprised that DreamWorks made puss in boots such good.i didn't believe Antonio Banderas play puss in boots so we'll and it's surprisingly the plot so good better than Disney and the character is good very much better than Disney film kiddos for DreamWorks for making this film. This is film is good for any age cause it got the thing that makes you fun, DreamWorks such a good upgrade l....... That's probably all the things that makes DreamWorks much more sent then it's competitor I hope DreamWorks made a more good film..... Kiddos for DreamWorks for make amazing film.

Part 1 was way better. Part 1 had a better story and animationstyle. Part one really had that wild west vibe, but this one not at all. I didnt like this new animationstyle, it is comicbooklike and too colourful. My opinion about this movie is that too much was happening at the same time, it was like they tried to show as much as possible in as little time as possible. They tried to make everything funny, but it didnt work for me most of the time, this made it really cringe.The storyline was also cliche and therefore predictable. When you are a fan of romantic, artsy animation movies, this one is definitely not worth your time and money.

I watched this movie in theaters and I couldn't believe it, it's been years since I saw such a beautiful animation, captivating and charismatic characters and a villain that every time he appeared I got goose bumps. The puss in boots was afraid because it was his last life and he didn't want to die, but at the end of the movie he changes his personality, he stopped being an arrogant guy who considered himself a legend for a person who fights for his own life even though he knew he couldn't defeat death, now he assumes that he is no longer a legend but a flawed person like everyone else. 10/10.

What a masterpiece! The animation was amazing, the characters were amazing, it was super funny and it was not afraid to get dark and gritty. Jumpscares were excellent, music was excellent, the whistle was golden! This was Cinema!

I was positively surprised by the film, compared to its predecessor, the narrative and animation evolution is remarkable, with 1 hour and 40 minutes of well-qualified entertainment. I really liked it.

Oi I'm gonna bust you up plumb thumb, them I'm gonna wear your clothes
That was weird
AUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUGHHHH

This movie is an absolute must watch. Puss in Boots: The Last Wish gives everything in a movie that I can ask for; A great plot, characters, and growth of the main character. A great sequel. For my extended review I will speak on aspects of the movie so if you do not want to be spoiled please do not read. First I would like to talk about Puss and his growth as a character. I absolutely love the way Puss goes from a prideful, arrogant, and irresponsible cat to something more mature and less reckless.  He learns that he is not indestructible and that he feels fear. Through this realization Puss does not run away from his problems anymore and decides to instead go head first into his biggest fear. Death. Which leads me to my second aspect of the film, the antagonist. In the movie there is a bundle of side antagonist who actually have a purpose and fit the story well. Each with their own motives and the writers did a great job explaining what they were after and why in such a short time. The lead antagonist Death was by far the best aspect of not only the film but also the development of Puss. He shows that Puss is both vulnerable and scared which leads him to face his fears and fight Death head on. Such a great antagonist to a great film. I would suggest leaving the franchise as it is and to not make a third movie so that they can't potentially ruin everything the second movie brought to the table. A must see movie.
The writing and animation in this story is perfection. We have the blue ray and still watch it all the time. Never gets boring.

Puss in Boots The Last Wish is an insanely good film. By far one of the best animated films to release recently. It is exciting, funny, and the story really packs a punch. Cannot recommend this one enough. Go see it!
ONE of the BEST DREAMWORKS movie, the Plot, Cinematography, Characters are great

A challenge to those who dare claim animation is just child's stuff. It has beautiful artwork, it's funny, heart filled, and has an antagonist who's probably going to go down as one of the best animated antagonist ever. I recommend it, even if you don't have any children to watch with you.
I can't believe this. This is the best animation of the year. My favorite animation of Dream Works. This is a Masterpiece.

Best spin-off movie I've ever seen, great casting that actually makes the characters feel so... real, ya know? Plot is over the top, both of the villains were amazing. This is genuinely the greatest movie to end with 2022. 9.5/10
Funny and hallarious a good family movie for everyone
This film restores your faith that creativity still exists in movie-making (which is even more amazing when it's a sequel).  Clever, funny, heartwarming and charming--'nuff said.

Puss in Boots, is, for the most part, a character that grew up with his audience. 

With this sequel coming out an entire decade after its predecessor, people definitely were not expecting this release. 

It's a rare thing when a sequel, especially a spin-off sequel, is met with open arms from audiences from sightings of a mere trailer, let alone an actual viewing. 

Puss in boots has a gorgeous stylisation, with a unique blend of 2D and 3D animation, that makes use of bold strokes, both within the literal art style and within the story beats themselves. Even the camera direction and angles used, alongside the editing is something that seriously lends to the viewing experience.

With unique character designs and bold, oversaturated use of colours, Puss in Boots: The Last Wish, is a film that isn't afraid to lean into its painterly and cartoonish roots to help convey mood and emotion within scenes, in a way that does not in any way retract from the experience. It, alternatively, lifts the viewing experience up immensely with the way in which it is done. 

It's a film that evokes unexpected emotion from the viewer, with scenes that tackle real life issues such as mental health struggles and even the concept of mortality and existential dread, with a realistic and raw approach, in a fashion typically not explored or portrayed in these styles of movie, at-least not with the level of care and tone-appropriate humour the film manages to utilise without denoting the character struggles.

This film also uses an interesting story telling mechanic, employed by having several characters within it that one could consider the ‘true antagonist' of the film depending on either the viewers perspective, or the time within the story as it progresses. The villains in this movie are all very three dimensional, and the level of foreshadowing that comes alongside that, is simply astounding. 

All in all, a film definitely worth a watch, and then another, to catch all of the details you might have missed the first time, thanks to that pesky yet effective foreshadowing.
Best Animated movie of all time and my new favourite movie of all time!!

It has been a long time since a new aesthetically pleasing villain was introduced in an animation film, whilst the past Puss in Boots movies have been fantastic this latest installation throws the previous into the dust. The animation style is stellar, vibrant and the character art is crisp and flourishing to see with the vfx effects. 

In a more in depth dive into the films pacing, at first the Giant being set up as the 'villain' but immediately losing to Puss set up an interesting perspective of 'who is the villain'. Whilst many would argue death is the main antagonist, he also equally isn't in a sense that his existence sets up Puss's own character development, death isn't evil he is instead a major factor in a characters growth. 

Overall the film takes you along the ride of seeing Puss not only as a character grow but also face his own fears as well as establish a bond with others as well.

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a terrific fantasy-adventure film spinning off from the Shrek universe. It follows the story of Puss, the charming fugitive feline who, following a scary encounter with Death, decides to stop his adventuring as he finds out he only has one life remaining. Soon after, his journey begins one again as he finds out the mystical Magic Wishing Star exists, with the ability to grant his one wish – the wish to reclaim his nine lives of course. 

This, however, is not an easy mission as other well-known fairy tale characters with a twist also battle for the wish. Overall, the epic quest is filled with hilarious, hearty and fearful moments, with an incredibly fleshed out storyline jam-packed with emotion and meaning. The film successfully explores themes of friendship, courage, love and ultimately the beauty that one life has to offer.
It is perfectly paced, with the main characters having sufficient and meaningful screen time, as well as an incredible dynamic with each other, and each scene having an importance and relevance. The animation is phenomenal and visually striking, and the action scenes are fast paced, smoothly transitioned, and spread out to keep the film intriguing. It is a one-of-a-kind film which has the ability to appeal to both kids and adults.

I would recommend this fantastic film to people of all ages, as this level of story-telling and striking animation is rare to find in today's cinema!

A rarity in Hollywood today - a movie that entertains.  Probably the best film ever made in the Shrek series, or at least of the Puss in Boots series.  Ostensibly a kid's film, this has something for everyone.  My teenagers, wife and I all loved it. It has wild half anime visual style, crazy action scenes, fairy tale craziness (although that shtick has dropped off since the original Shrek).  The humor is not wall to wall, but organic, and almost always lands.  But more importantly, it has more mature themes of coming to grips with mortality and life priorities.  It is an emotional roller coaster and really well done.  Yeah it is a little cartoonish sure, but it IS a kids' film.

This may just be my favorite movie of all time. Not the best movie, The Prince of Egypt and A Beautiful Day in The Neighborhood are the best movies I've seen, but Puss In Boots: The Last Wish is a must-watch. Even as someone who didn't like the first movie, I think this movie soars in every aspect. Puss, Kitty, and Perrito are a great cast of main characters, each of which feel grounded and entertaining at the same time. This movie having 3 villains could have made it feel overstuffed and like it was doing too much, but no one villain takes time from the others and they're all so well written. Jack Horner is a refreshing villain, he is completely irredeemable and evil, something that Disney should do more with its villains if they ever decide to have an actual villain again. Goldilocks and the 3 bears are incredibly sympathetic, well written characters, they're some of my favorites. Wolf was so threatening, generating chills any time he was onscreen. The animation of this movie is so stylized and gorgeous and puts what the first Puss in Boots did to shame. The music is great, "Fearless Hero" is one of my favorite songs from a movie, there's a reason everyone remembers this song after seeing this movie. I could go on and on, but you get the point. Puss In Boots: The Last Wish is an uncontested masterpiece, by far my favorite Dreamworks movie

(SPOILER WARNING) (TLDR AT THE BOTTOM)

This is what animated kids movies should be like. Behind all of the bright colours of the gorgeous animation, making all of the action scenes an absolute spectacle to feast your eyes onto, is a simple plot with an absolutely massive impact. 

The story is light hearted enough so kids can get enjoyment out of it, but it also treats its audience with maturity, not playing safe and having the ‘bravery' to insert extremely deep messages. One of which is the over-arching theme of mortality and how we need to appreciate what we have.

This theme is represented beautifully through its characters. The protagonist puss in boots learns how he has taken his lives for granted. He learns this through the other characters such as Perrito. 

At first glance he seems like the cliché annoying side character for comic relief, but turns out being a warm, friendly and extremely likeable little chap. The fact that he does not have a wish, along with some other character traits, shows us and puss how he is content with the life he has, and only looks forward to his simple dreams, letting the rest develop along the way. His dream is to become a therapy dog, which is an important detail to note further into the film. 

Of course I cannot review this movie without mentioning Death, one of the best animated villains I have seen in a while. He shows puss his hatred towards him for taking his lives for granted, and enjoys inflicting fear into other people. In his introduction scene he is extremely close to taking puss' final life, coming as close to a scar on his forehead, with one drop of blood slowly creeping down to his shocked face. (Another example of this film's maturity) in this scene we see puss experience true fear for the first time in his life, as he is petrified of dying right there, right then. This is the moment he comes to realise how much he has taken for granted, and it was all at the fault of this menacing wolf character.

But it doesn't stop there, he constantly torments puss, showing up throughout random parts of the film, in which every appearance, send massive chills down puss' and my spine, with his truly uncanny whistle. 

One of these appearances leads to what is in my opinion one of the most powerful scenes in the film. Puss begins to run away in a state of absolute to panic before coming to a stop. We see that he is struggling to breathe, and his vision is blurry. Perrito is the only one there, and without any dialogue, Perrito simply rests his head on puss' chest, and in a slow decent into calmness, puss regains his control. Perrito has completed his dream of being a therapy dog. The shear realism of this scene, along with the mature dealing of the situation is what makes this scene, and this film in general truly one of a kind. 

To finalise, we also have many other great characters, most notably, Goldi the three bears, the redeemable villains who learn to appreciate their family, and Big Jack Horner, the pure evil villain who does not appreciate what he has at all, to which he learns to consequences. Overall he is an extremely funny character with a ‘charming evil' to him. All of these characters are balanced out perfectly through the films perfect pacing. Nothing seems to drag on at all.

TLDR:
This movie is an incredible creation. All the characters are amazing in their respected ways, the animation is a true spectacle of passion and creativity, and the plot is simple, but truly impactful with the balance of light hearted humour and the downright mature themes. 

Personal experience:
I have never felt so much towards a film before, the mature themes especially hit hard and really made me look over how I spend my one life. I would honestly not recommend this film to really young audiences, because this film is best experienced when you truly understand the mature tones and messages. I absolutely adored this film, and I hope you did as well.

P.S. this is my first proper review of a film, so sorry if some parts are a bit confusing, and the pacing on this is no where near as good as the films lol. There's so much to say but I don't want this to be too long. But still if you made it this far, even if skipping to the TLDR, thanks for reading, hope i expressed my opinions well enough.

A very funny, colorful and well animated movie. Puss in Boots: The Last Wish goes surprisingly deep into its main character giving a multi-layered personality and a very satisfying character development. The whole cast is particularly efficient to hook you up in their adventure, protagonists and antagonists all shine in their way and give you new favorites in the Shrek Universe. 
Things go fast here since the main goal is to entertain Puss in Boots don't take too much time in event that would usually ask for a little more development. It's notable but not necessarily a bad thing since the characters really help to smooth things with how they command the pacing.
The Last Wish is unexpectedly violent with literal deaths in it, a few drops of bloods, and one of the character is scary. Not a bad point actually, I found it pretty great that they dared to push a little the boundaries of family entertainment.
With a great script and a beautiful final message, Puss in Boots is one of the best animations in the studio and a great movie to watch as a family.

This is a beautiful movie. It worked for and completely earns all of the praise it gets. 

It was visually fantastic. It was emotionally moving. They did a wonderful job telling the story. Even the parts I initially thought would be annoying were great. It was perfectly balanced and had such good messages throughout. 

This movie reminds you to appreciate life and what you have, to live in the moment, to make the most of the time you have, to not let fear control you but that it is ok to be afraid sometimes you just need to work to overcome it. It supports strong family connections, whether that family is biological or not. The antagonists/villains are superb.  It's really funny but still gives the emotional moments time to breath. And this is from a sequel movie to a spinoff about a swashbuckling cat. 

So many movies are the equivalent of junk food and we just keep accepting it and getting more of the same.

Movies like this need to be praised and supported. It's the only way to send a message that we are tired of the constant junk thrown at us.

Enormous thanks to everyone involved with the creation of this gem.

beg for mercy from puss! in boots!

the concept for this film is simple, puss has run out of his nine lives and can only get them back with the means of a wishing star which is in pretty high demand among the bad guys of the shrek cinematic universe. the competition is Goldilocks and the Three Bears and Little Jack Horner who is not so little anymore along with a certain someone who is behind puss for a very specific reason.

the execution of this concept is what makes this film such a treat. the screenplay is straightforward and fast-paced, drags somewhat in the second act but manages itself by the end. the music is perfect for the aesthetic (chef's kiss to be more accurate). the voice acting is muy buena (very good). Antonio Banderas, Salma Hayek, Florence Pugh, Harvey Guillén, John Mulaney, Wagner Moura they're all just fantastic. I was genuinely invested in the characters and not solely on nostalgia. not that this film does a few callbacks but those aren't some cheap fan-services but something that add a little substance to the greater story.

now, the animation and the cinematography. ughhhh, it's so freaking beautiful !!! spiderverse swung in style so puss in boots could land perfecttly on it's feet. there is clearly inspiration for the animation here but instead of some cheap rip-off, it really feels like an artistic choice and comes off as an artist's fairytale come to life here. the movie literally starts with the words "this is a fairytale..." and lives up to it! the cinematography too is something to look out for. this film haz better shots than I can spot in a big budget Hollywood blockbuster these days. DreamWorks atleast never fails in that department and always manages to exceed expectations!

to be honest, I wasn't really expecting anything from this film because the shrek cinematic universe has been near-dead for so long, but this film gives me hope. this film gives me something to put my faith in. you'd think that years of development hell would usually mean bad for a film but not for PUSS!... IN BOOTS!

just go and have a good time with this. and if you haven't yet seen the trailer for the film, don't do it. just go into the film blindly like I did. It will surely give you a few surprises! in my opinion, this is the best film in the Shrek Cinematic Universe since Shrek 2, which isn't saying a lot, but it should since Shrek: Forever After was the only good film after Shrek 2.

P.S.: the new DreamWorks intro is so good. I just love it!

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a truly amazing movie, by FAR the scariest villain I've seen in a while. When he come on screen and the whistling just gave me chills it was perfect, its was like i were being hunted by the one and only death like i can feel the fear he carries. Great project for a kids movie, it add a lot of story to puss like the way he revealed his true colors at the end of the movie and the friendships he have along with the adventures he have, showing that puss is a huge character in the Shrek universe even one of the strongest he last against death in a battle. I really like how they end the movie, SPOILERS they way death gave him a chance at life because he showed who he really is and hes not that overconfident guy who think he can work alone, he shows that he have heart. Death was no longer searching for that same guy anymore he saw his true self i love that, instead of just making it where they made death surrender or die OR show that hes weak. The moral of the story and the text make a lot of sense and was inspiring truly an experience.

The villain in this movie is really scary and the whistling sound that he make gave me chills. I could feel the fear that he carry, like I was being hunted by Death himself. This movie is a great project for kids because it add a lot of story to Puss in Boots' character. We see him reveal his true colors at the end of the movie, and the friendships he have along with the adventures he go on. This show that Puss is a huge character in the Shrek universe and even one of the strongest because he last against Death in a battle.

I really like how the movie end. SPOILERS Death gave Puss a chance at life because he showed who he really is and he's not just an overconfident guy who think he can work alone. He show that he have heart. Death was no longer searching for that same guy anymore because he saw Puss's true self. I love that the movie didn't just make Death surrender or die, or show that he's weak. The moral of the story and the text make a lot of sense and was truly inspiring. The movie is a great reminder that it's important to show our true selves and that we can all change for the better.

In conclusion, Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a great movie that you should definitely watch. The story is engaging, the characters are interesting, and the villain is truly scary. The movie add a lot of depth to Puss in Boots' character, showing that he's a strong and complex character in the Shrek universe. The movie's ending is satisfying and inspiring, reminding us of the importance of being true to ourselves. If you're a fan of Shrek or just looking for a great family movie, Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is definitely worth a watch.

puss in boots: the last wish is the greatest movie of all time. It saved my firstborn, cured my illnesses, cured my depression, stopped climate change, saved animation as a medium, killed Donald trump, and solved world hunger. In conclusion, the wolf should step on me.

It's great, one of the better movies lately. The characters are great and relatable in various ways, not as flat as expected from animated movie. Love that studio started experimenting with animation styles, and it's not just another standartised 3D jig (looking at you Pixar and your recent years of work that's becoming increasingly muddied stylistically). 
I'm not sure whether Puss in Boots is going to have another story, but I'm pleasantly surprised about where Dreamworks could go after seeing Puss in Boots.

Time to wake up, Disney. Dreamworks has long been eating your lunch, and Puss just finished your dessert. I cannot praise this movie enough. It's a visual feast, hilarious in places and sombre and honest where it counts (and they let the hard-hitting moments linger, none of this wisecracking a joke right away that the MCU does just in case the audience stops laughing for 3 seconds).

The Last Wish is a breath of fresh air. It doesn't harp on at the audience; it doesn't lecture, and it doesn't reiterate the typical "environment good, white men bad" rhetoric that Disney has been repeating since they turned awful. Puss carries a genuinely essential and universal message about making the most of your life, overcoming hardships and bad luck and coming out all the stronger for it with an appreciation for what you have. It may be hard for modern audiences to relate to putting others' needs before your own instant selfish gratification, but it's nice that that's also a theme.

It's fantastic, and I would love to see more studios returning to a more wholesome and honest approach to making movies. Enough woke BS

I watched the movie for the first time a little under two months ago and can I just say, I was in awe. I was in Florida, visiting my grandparents for vacation and it was one of the first things I wanted to do with my grandma while there. I had heard a lot of praise for the movie from my friends (age range 14-20) and since I'm an enjoyer of animation in the first place, I went to go see it. Now, I will say I went into this with little background of how the first movie went - I had watched it once, and that was several years prior. Good thing about The Last Wish, though - you don't need too much background information, so to an extent it can work as a standalone movie if you really want it to be. Going into the actual movie, WOW! The animation was absolutely stunning. They definitely took a lot of inspiration from Into The Spiderverse regarding the animation, mixing the 2D and 3D together. I've seen several reviews saying that made it "hard to watch" or "look cheap", but it was quite the opposite, quite dynamic! It was also very colorful and very detailed, but not too much so - "just right", as Goldilocks would say. Speaking of Goldilocks: regarding the characters, I think they were also very well done. It's easy to root for Puss, he's not one of those protagonists that you get bored and annoyed with, especially with Kitty and Perrito supporting him in his leading role. The villains of the movie were also very well done: Death (the wolf) was quite ominous and accurately embodied Death, "straight up". Goldilocks was a flawed character rather than an actual evil one, and it was nice that her story and wish was resolved at the end in a sweet way, though I will say if I have any critiques at all you could see that from a mile away. Jack Horner, though being the most unapologetically evil character, is also one of the funniest and most memorable of all. Killer design, funny lines, John Mulaney did such a great job voicing him. In fact, all of the voice actors and actresses were flawless - they fit their characters and fit the tones perfectly. 
A lot of reviews against this movie say it's too dark, but I think that's what makes this movie so beautiful. Yes, one of the main topics is mortality, and if that's not something you are ready to talk about with your child - assuming that's who you're going to bring to the movie - then do not bring them. However, if you want them to be able to discuss and see the topic of mortality in a healthy, safe way, this is definitely the movie for you. A lot of media these days struggles in how to discuss death. I think The Last Wish definitely illustrates how ominous and scary the topic of death may be, with its personification of death (the wolf character). At the same time, Puss is able to tackle his fear of death in the end. 
All things considered, this movie absolutely knocked it out of the park. There is so much to enjoy out of this movie, from humor, fun characters, sweet moments, dynamic fight scenes (which do NOT take up the whole movie, by the way!), absolutely GORGEOUS animation, and a killer soundtrack that doesn't get enough credit...and of course, the fact that there is a lot to think about after watching it. 
I highly recommend this movie. Treat yourself and/or your loved ones and go watch it.

A sequel to an average spin-off film that struggles to make its own name somehow has a sequel more than a decade later that excels at everything cinema is missing these days. Great storytelling, great villains, excellent character journeys and a kid's film that has more profound and more mature themes that even 12A and 15 films lack. While I admit the Wolf may be slightly too scary for the age range it appeals to in its more vibrant child-like audience, I think it fits into a wider family film that has its laughs for the kids while not being afraid to make an emotional effect on the grown-ups. Kids and grown-ups love this film alike, just what a FAMILY film should do. Family films are now more kid's films that grown-ups watch out of necessity, but Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is hopefully the start of animation going back to being a family occasion and not just a kids-only appeal. Dreamworks could be onto the renaissance of animation, and if the same team is working on Shrek 5, I am definitely on board.

This is the first time where I have seen the audience scores aligned with the critic scores. Normally, I would say critic scores are trying to be cooperate-friendly and be as nice as possible to the movie(the exact opposite of what a critic is ironically), but I have to say, the critic and audience score is very justified. I may or may not update this post, because I have only seen this movie once.

So right now, I am going to be upfront, and write my critiques out of the way so I can talk about the good stuff after.

So, I don't know if it's the effects of my sensory issues and loud movie theater speakers clashing, but it induced a bit of anxiety in me. It could've just be the first few minutes kind of rushing through along with other effects, or it was just loud speakers and my sensitive ears colliding. I really don't know, I would have to rewatch so other time to see. The first few minutes are kind of just a fuzzy memory to me.

I also don't know why they didn't just address the problem between Puss and Soft-paws earlier in the movie. There isn't necessarily anything bad about it, but I feel it would've been better addressed earlier.

That's really my only concerns, not even a problem really.

I think that all the villians are all pretty solid for there being multiple villains. You know what. Scratch that. They aren't just solid villains. They are all really good villains. Plain an simple. 

Jack Horner isn't trying to be relatable at all. He doesn't have some sad back story that tries to get you to sympathize with him. He is just pure evil. He believes only he should be entitled to his power, doesn't give a damn about anyone else, and would do anything to get what he want, even if it means needlessly putting others lives at risk, even those who dedicate there services to him. It is a bit more refreshing to see that we aren't being guilt tripped through a story, and we are being shown that evil isn't made because of bad things. It can just be made in anyone, regardless. Plain and simple. 

He also isn't 2 dimensional either. He might not have a conscious telling him what right and wrong is, but you are shown he has a reason for doing it, even if you don't understand his ideologies or reasonings. It is showcased in ways that you understand what he is doing and why. He knows that once he gets his hands on the power, no one will be able to stop him anyway, and he is confident he can get it.

Ohhh… and death. Death is just amazing to watch on screen. He literally gave me the chills anytime he was on screen, and I love it. That's how you right a villain. When his presence on screen is so intense, that you get chills just seeing him. He is just a badass. Through and through. Nothing else. And I don't mean it metaphorically or rhetorically or poetically or theoretically or any other fancy way. He is a total badass. Straight. Up.

He has so many memorable quotes, I just can't help but reference them as I am writing this review! He is genuinely that fun and memorable as a villain!!! 

He also has a motive that isn't just clear like Jack Horners, but you understand why. And you don't just understand why, his motives are almost justified. You almost root for him at times.

Not to mention Puss in Boots arc where he goes from arrogant ass who doesn't truly value his lives until he realizes he doesn't have any to lose, to one who would like to spend his life wisely and happily, realizing what life is.

Everyone going after the wish has a reason to go after the wish, and then they realize they had what they wished for, and it's just so good. It shows that you could learn to look at what you have and not take it for granted.

I could go on for hours and hours why this movie was such a good movie. But I bet you probably came here for a shorter review just to see if this movie. You didn't come for a whole essay. So I am going to cut it short here and save everyone including myself time. This movie is going to be one of the highest ratings I may ever give to a movie. It's that good. Watch it as soon as possible.

The new sequel to the puss in boots franchise is definitely one one of the best Dreamworks movie that I have seen since Kung Fu Panda 3. DreamWorks is clearly saying with this movie that they are now king of the hill in animation films. The animation is incredible and the cast of characters is great. The one thing that sticks out though is the character Death. In my opinion one of the scariest villains in animation history, he defies in any scene giving you goosebumps along with an incredibly intimidating voice given by the talented Wagner Moura. If this is the new standard of what DreamWorks is going to make, I can confidentially say for everyone, we are excited and hope for the best. But please no more Trolls or Boss Baby.
The animated film is fantastic in every way. And I don't mean it metaphorically or rhetorically, Or poetically or theoretically, or in any other fancy way. Straight up, great movie.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is a thrilling adventure that will have you on the edge of your seat - and it's not just because of the swashbuckling hero himself. DreamWorks has outdone themselves with this latest installment in the franchise, and one of the highlights is the mind-blowing performance by Death Wolf.

This new character, voiced by the talented Idris Elba, is a force to be reckoned with. His menacing presence and cunning tactics make him a worthy adversary for Puss in Boots and his new allies. And when Death Wolf finally unleashes his full power, the results are truly awe-inspiring.

But Death Wolf is just one of many memorable characters in this movie. Puss in Boots, voiced once again by the incomparable Antonio Banderas, is as swashbuckling and charming as ever. And the addition of new allies like Dulcinea (voiced by the delightful Tiffany Haddish) adds depth and heart to the story.

ง

Of course, it wouldn't be a DreamWorks movie without stunning animation and plenty of humor. "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" delivers on both counts, with breathtaking visuals and plenty of laughs to keep audiences of all ages entertained.

In a world where animated movies are a dime a dozen, "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" stands out as a true gem. With its unforgettable characters, thrilling story, and mind- blowing performance by Idris Elba, it's a must-see for anyone who loves great movies.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" is an absolute delight from start to finish, bringing back the swashbuckling feline hero we all know and love in a brand new adventure that will leave audiences purring with delight. With stunning animation, hilarious humor, and heartwarming moments that will tug at your heartstrings, DreamWorks has once again proven that they are the masters of family-friendly entertainment.

While Disney may have a storied history of creating classic animated films, "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" shows that DreamWorks is truly a force to be reckoned with. From the intricate character designs to the intricate fight scenes, every aspect of this film has been expertly crafted with care and attention to detail.

If you're looking for a movie that will transport you to a magical world filled with adventure, romance, and plenty of laughs, then look no further than "Puss in Boots: The Last Wish." DreamWorks has truly outdone themselves with this latest installment in the beloved franchise, and it's a must-see for anyone who loves great animation and storytelling.

One of Dreamworks best movies and honestly one of my favorite animated films of all time. The Last Wish is just amazing all around and I'm really happy now that more stylized animation is being used by other studios in a really cool way. This movie was one of the last movies that I thought was going to be really good but I'm very happy that it went above and beyond what I thought it was going to be. The story is pretty cliche and generic yes but it's everything around the story that makes this film so good. The animation is incredibly. The Spider-Verse style works very well for this film and it still stands out from Spider-Verse in its own unique way. The characters and their own respective arcs are great. There really isn't one weak character here. Puss himself gets some excellent development and his journey of grabbing with the concept of death is very emotional and well written. Kitty Softpaws also has a really good arc and chemistry with Puss and Perrito has some really great moments. All of the villains here are great. Goldilocks and the 3 bears all have a good arc and Jack Horner is one of the funniest characters ever included in an animated film and works amazingly well as the irredeemable villain but the real standout here is Death. Death is probably one of if not the best Dreamworks villain. To have Death be personified and built up the way it is in the film is just something else. His interactions with Puss were always amazing. The humor was great as well. Pretty much every joke from Jack landed and all the other jokes were really great as well. Everyone involved with this film felt like they really cared about the characters and the story and that's what makes the film so great. I would highly recommend checking this film out as it's genuinely one of the best films of 2022 and one of the best animated movies ever.

"Puss in Boots: The Last Wish" absolutely took my breath away. This work of art provides everything you could ask for in an animated film. The animation was superb, with a slight action style that added a unique spark to the already beautiful visuals, which had such a variety of themes. Plus, the character design. I'm still getting over how amazing the wolf looked, absolutely horrifying but so fun to watch. The direction was one of the best I've seen in any animated movie, with stunning shots that I'm shocked other films haven't used. The worldbuilding was so compelling, with elements of fantasy and adventure so interesting and thought-provoking, and ideas so brilliant I've truly never seen anything like it. The voice acting was perfect, casting celebrities that are actually good at voice acting, and actors I've never seen before that still were great. The characters were set up so well, with emotional sequences and character building that was heartfelt and realistic, despite the movie being about talking animals and fictional creatures. The comedy was wonderful, with Disney parodies and fairy tale references, plus sequences that were extremely funny. There's practically nothing wrong with this movie- everything was so riveting and fun to watch, always entertaining you while keeping you in suspense. Overall, this is one of the best movies I've ever seen, animated or not. I was invested throughout the entire experience, rooting for characters in their toughest moments, and genuinely tearing up multiple times. This movie is outstanding.

My first cinema experience of 2023, and what a good one it was. I didn't have high expectations - I decided on a whim to see it after two recommendations in separate, unrelated YouTube videos. I didn't even remember this is a sequel. Nevertheless, it was fantastic, and a fantastic standalone film. The animation style is delightful, and similar in many ways to Into The Spiderverse, with an overall painterly, comic book aesthetic and creative use of variable frame rate and colour. The story brilliantly balances real heart with cracking jokes. The characters are all super endearing and energetically acted - suave Puss and his old flame Kitty, effervescent Perrito, relentlessly, comedically cruel Jack Horner, surprisingly familial Goldi and her three bears, and the spectre following Puss everywhere. The story is interesting, taking someone who has grown to think himself untouchable and challenging him to stop thinking about himself for once, and along the way a loner learns to trust again, a dog with the saddest backstory finds a loving family, and an adopted child comes to appreciate her found family. So much else to love - the Shrek cameos, the touching portrayal of a panic attack, the in-universe theme song ("He is your favourite fearless hero"), the touches of anime in fight choreography. I can't wait to see it again.

"The Last Wish" might very well be DreamWorks' magnum opus; at bare minimum, it's one of their best by far. I have seen very few films that have successfully nailed such a strong balance of comedy, action, poignant moments, and -- surprisingly -- legitimate horror; that TLW manages to pull this off while being a mostly-child-friendly animated film is deserving of praise. While it doesn't quite reach perfection, it comes remarkably close. A must-see for anyone with even a passing interest in animated films.

In my entire life, I have never gone out of my way to rate any movie. Yet watching this…was just a pure pleasure. Never before did I enjoy watching something as I had with Puss in Boots: The Last Wish. I'm always an active critic, yelling in my mind on why the movie is terrible and unrealistic while I'm watching it, yet I didn't do that at all while watching this. 

The story plot line is perfect, it is somewhat bit more fast paced but there is 0 filler or unnecessary moments. Each and every part seems to contribute to a lesson or meaning, and really builds each of the characters that we see in the short amount of time (less than 2 hours). The buildup is solid and the ending is amazing.

The voice acting is flat down some of the best I've ever heard for any animated movie, fantastic and describes each character exactly. I actually never noticed this about any other movies but it really stood out to me from this one. 

Overall the movie is a 10/10, from a solid critics viewpoint.

Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a masterpiece. The movie was over 10 years in the making and it shows. Not a single part of it feels rushed, forced, or poorly done. It has gotten stellar reviews on all fronts because the movie is flawless in every regard. It's no wonder that a fantastically executed depiction of one of the most consistently beloved characters in history makes for the greatest movie of all time.
The movie utilizes an animation style inspired by Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, a movie similarly praised by critics, nigh on universally for its fantastic art. Dreamworks used this same system in the production of Puss in Boots, another example of why the decade-long wait after its original announcement contributed to how truly spectacular the movie is. The painting-like style of art created an atmosphere that felt very much like a fairy-tale as opposed to the just-off-reality vibe that CGI movies of the past had, or the totally devoid of realism style of completely hand-drawn movies such as Aladdin or the Lion King. Dreamworks gave us the best that there is in the animated world by refusing to hold back on the art style. The fact that all movies with higher acclaim amongst critics happen to be live action only serves to illustrate why this movie isn't considered better by so called professionals.
	This art-style helps contribute to the simply stunning fight scenes in Puss in Boots: The Last Wish. However, the visuals are not the only thing that makes the swordsmanship in this movie stand out. Unlike other movies using swords, The Last Wish holds a great degree of accuracy to real life swordsmanship. In every single fight, it is clear who is attacking who, who is on offense, who is on defense. Puss can be seen parrying, and then counter attacking with a well executed riposte just like in real fencing. Puss' fight with Death at the end of the movie is the most spectacular fight throughout, with both characters showing off the true height of their ability, utilizing their respective advantages in speed, dexterity, strength, size, cunning, and more and not just pointlessly slapping sticks together between them. What's more, Puss' use of a so-called ‘gatito blade' in his offhand, is highly consistent with the use of parrying daggers, which were quite popular in Italy and Spain for use in rapier fencing. Such historical accuracy is quite rare in TV shows and movies, and for it to be found in a children's movie where that is rarely a concern just goes to show how much effort was put into the movie. Finer details such as these serve to show just how great of flawless masterpiece this movie really is. What's more, every fight in the movie serves a purpose other than just violence for the sake of violence. They help create exposition, advance the plot, and develop characters, whether that be by showing ‘Big' Jack Horner's ruthlessness, the strengthening of Three Bears familial bonds, or galvanizing Puss to be brave and value his lives and the time he has with his friends.
The message of the story is found in the final fight scene. Without having to be explicitly said, the message is still clear, you should cherish every second. The movie also has much to say about how it's ok to be afraid, a lesson many young boys, and all men really, need to hear. It has a flawless and nuanced depiction of a panic attack, something that can't be said for most movies, and shows us that we don't always have as much control as we thought we did, and that's ok. Therein lies the elegance of Puss in Boots: The Last Wish. It is, at its heart, a children's movie, and therefore has the obligation to leave the audience with a clear and positive message. This is no easy task for a movie to accomplish without being heavy handed. Luckily, for the Last Wish, the movie is far from heavy handed, with every message in the story being flawlessly woven into the very essence of the movie, instead of being carelessly stapled on top like so many other movies do. The reward of being appropriate for all audiences and for leaving them all with a positive message is incalculable and one of the many reasons Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is greater than any other movie, despite their higher approval amongst critics.
Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is a work of art. It is not only accessible to all audiences, but entertaining to them as well. It surrounds a beloved character that is a known-quantity in his beloved status amongst all, and does him justice in innumerable ways. The movie's attention to detail, and sheer visual beauty set it apart from any other animated movie ever made, while its character development, positive messages, and ability to stay within a PG rating puts it far ahead the dark live action movies that dominate the highest rated spots amongst movie review websites. Dreamworks didn't hold back on this one and, on God, it shows.

Just as everyone expected, a sequel to a spin-off to the Shrek franchise that took 11 years to arrive in theatres was the animated movie that took the world by storm. 

The Last Wish really did defy expectations, assuming people had any. The animation style was refreshing for the franchise, the humor was more balanced with the character-driven story, and despite maintaining three different villains the film feels solid rather than clunky. Instead of frequent pop culture references and dodgy jokes that pad for time in the later Shrek films, this Puss in Boots sequel weaves the influences of classic Spaghetti Westerns and swashbuckler films with a family adventure storyline and affirmative, positive themes about appreciating life and those around you. It knows when to be lighthearted and when to be serious, and introduces us to one of the coolest original villains in family animation - a wolf embodiment of death - by not holding back on the menacing aura and instead focusing on it; hopefully the sense of danger will encourage other franchises to stop oversanitizing their films. If I were in the movie's target audience, it would probably be a film I would swear by for the rest of my life (sort of like Shrek 2), but in this case I'll just call it a very good family movie that came out of nowhere.

I hope you're all ready for more Shrek because now it's basically guaranteed to happen. And they will likely be disappointing. (3.5/5)

Alright I know what you’re thinking after seeing the score of this review. “Sequels to spin-offs of beloved franchises are pointless exercises in brand awareness! Why on earth are you giving this one a 10?!?”Because this movie…is DIFFERENTAlright I know what you’re thinking after seeing the score of this review. “Sequels to spin-offs of beloved franchises are pointless exercises in brand awareness! Why on earth are you giving this one a 10?!?”Because this movie…is DIFFERENT than the others. Different in that it strives to be a funnier, deeper, prettier, bolder, edgier, (surprisingly) scarier and overall more complete experience than the original Puss in Boots film over 11 years ago, and unlike that movie holds a distinct accomplishment in simply being a darn fine animated film that stands on its own, one as good as any I’ve seen in the past few years.The Shrekiverse is officially back, and judging by what DreamWorks managed to pull off here the world probably isn’t ready for whatever comes next.PS: That cricket with the spot-on Jimmy Stewart voice is one of the funniest things I’ve seen this year, whoever came up with him deserves a pay raise and a medal and free coffee and recognition from the United Nations.

Puss in Boots: The last wish was ten times better than IIf you like movies with great animation styles, deep and interesting characters, a bit of tackling of serious themes like death, and good humour then this one is definitely for you. Puss in Boots: The last wish was ten times better than I expected. I went into the theatres expecting an alright movie perfect for an afternoon with nothing else to do, I however got out with my head and heart both in shock after the shear amount of love this film has into it.1) The animation: It definitely is inspired on the style of Into The Spiderverse, and it fits into this movie perfectly. The fight scenes look phenomenal, the colour pallette is bright and interesting to look at, and the world Dreamworks created always captivated me especially for the second half of the film.2) Characters: Puss himself is at the centre of the film, with many side characters around him also experiencing personal growth and learning important life values and lessons. The Dog character is not irritating at all, and he even helped Puss and Kitty throughout their adventure. There are no filler characters, all of them fit nicely into the narrative and into the conflict, and are relatable to the audience which is crucial in a character growth driven story. To put it shortly, all characters have believable and relatable fears, emotions and goals which help in selling the ultimate message of the film perfectly.3) The message: Despite being targeted for all ages, this movie contains many scary scenes and deals with serious themes such as anxiety, trauma and death, all of these through the character of Puss himself. Being on his last life, Puss is confronted with the reality that death is nearer than ever, which pushes him into the adventure that unfolds in the film. The ultimate message I won't spoil, but you could already figure out what it is. It's perfect, beautiful, and inspiring for anyone who watches it. 4) The humour: I wouldn't say I laughed as hard as I did with Kung Fu Panda, but thankfully the film has good jokes that land well enough and made me chuckle many times. Don't think that it has silly fart jokes or kid humour, because this film doesn't. Conclusion: Ultimately this is one of the best film I've watched this year. I will probably go many times to the cinema just to watch it, it's beautifully animated, the characters are well written and are developped flawlessly, it ends with a beautiful message and deals with severe themes which everyone can learn something from, and to top it all of arrives just in time for christmas. I'm serious, go watch this movie if you still haven't, I'm sure you'll get out just as surprised as I was. Definitely recommended.

I absolutely loved this movie it was so deep for a kids movie and was incredibly entertaining for all ages. The humor was classic and the story line with the twists off of fairy tales and nursery rhymes was amazing

Antonio Banderas returns as the voice of the swashbuckling cat. After a splashy opening song and a quick getaway, Puss discovers that he's blown thru 8 of his 9 lives and sets out to get the titular wish. Along the way he picks up someAntonio Banderas returns as the voice of the swashbuckling cat. After a splashy opening song and a quick getaway, Puss discovers that he's blown thru 8 of his 9 lives and sets out to get the titular wish. Along the way he picks up some additional supporting characters. The visuals are vivid and colorful, but that's pretty standard for animations these days. What gives this film its oomph is the pacing, which keeps the action moving. Even though some of the new assortment of individuals has fun delivery, the biggest missing element is comedy. Ever since Trek, these films are usually crammed with clever quips and snarky references. There are some here, but it lacks punch and punchlines. Still, there's enough energy for those who want another experience with the franchise.

When I first saw the trailer I remembered that the first movie wasn't amazing it was OK, but this film WOW it is stellar, this is the quality I expect from Dreamworks. The passion, the glory, the boots of this film truly reminded me of Shrek 2. The action is really well animated even if its chopped down a few frames, the scenes and cinematography are powerful and exiting combined with some music flares.The Visuals are really great to look at, but there are some scenes I've noticed where they looked a bit off, like it was a Pre-3D render without lighting I don't know if it Jack Horners' Face that threw me off a bit but it looked bad in some scenes.The story is generic in the last half of the film, they maybe should have stretched it out a little bit by 10 mins with some mystery, or more exploration. One would never think a sequel to a long forgotten Shrek spinoff movie would be one of Dreamworks' best projects ever, and yet Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is just that. The film is gorgeously animated, featuring a 2D/3D hybrid similar to theOne would never think a sequel to a long forgotten Shrek spinoff movie would be one of Dreamworks' best projects ever, and yet Puss in Boots: The Last Wish is just that. The film is gorgeously animated, featuring a 2D/3D hybrid similar to the likes of Spider-Verse and Mitchells vs. the Machines, yet improved upon in some manners. The voice cast is beyond exceptional, from the returning actors in Antonio Banderas and Salma Hayek, as well as newcomers in Florence Pugh and John Mulaney. Finally, and most important, the writing of this film is masterful, blending both excellent humor aimed at a more mature audience (like the Shrek movies) and deep subject matter relating to making the most of the life we do have and the people we spend it with, all of which told in a great story. I cannot recommend this film enough, and I cannot wait for more returns to Far Far Away in the future Shrek installments this is setting up.

This movie took me completely by surprise. I've watched the earlier Puss in Boots movie and frankly found it to be quite dull.But this one is another matter! It's zany, witty, action-packed, sweet and a glory to behold! Sometimes swervingThis movie took me completely by surprise. I've watched the earlier Puss in Boots movie and frankly found it to be quite dull.But this one is another matter! It's zany, witty, action-packed, sweet and a glory to behold! Sometimes swerving into old-school animation-style scenes during the action where it sort of mimics the style of "Into the Spiderverse" where it runs at about 15 frames per second making it look sort of like stop-motion. It's odd since they use this effect only in fast-paced action sequences and mix it with some almost 2D-centric effects. It works well, but it does take a bit getting used to. But I think I like it!The movie itself starts out a bit slow in the first 10 minutes where we sort of get the usual run-of-the-mill musical scene that always bore me to death. But I now realize that THAT scene was actually quite important for the overall plot of the movie. And the style of it as well. So now I kind of appreciate it being there. But it did make me want to turn the movie off, so I'm glad I stuck with it. I'd heard good things about it, so that made me stay.And I'm glad I did. There's some really fun and lovable characters in this one. And throughout the movie you'll realize that almost the entire movie itself becomes a character transforming and molding itself as the story unfolds. Hard to explain, just watch it! You won't regret it.
